<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning. </strong><em>Mulan </em>comes out on Disney+ today, but let's be real—the Disney live-action remakes have been underwhelming.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Maybe they're thinking about it all wrong. What if...and hear us out...Disney started doing animation remakes instead? So taking its live-action movies and turning them into animated films?</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">There is one obvious choice for the first animated remake: <em>Pirates of the Caribbean. </em></p>

Many analysts say this was a healthy pullback from weeks of ludicrous gains.</span>

<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Trade: </strong></span><span>The U.S. trade deficit (difference between imports and exports) grew to its </span><span><a href="https://apnews.com/dd93ecd3cafc5df88a8f9f4a61693b07?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">highest level</a></span><span> since 2008 in July. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Jobs: </strong></span><span>New jobless claims = </span><span><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-economy/u-s-weekly-jobless-claims-below-one-million-but-labor-market-recovery-ebbing-idUSKBN25U1WS?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">881,000 last week</a></span><span>, better than expectations. However, this was the first weekly report that reflected a new Labor Department methodology for calculating seasonal fluctuations. The big August jobs report is out this morning. </span>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TECH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/03/tech-platforms-implement-measures-curb-misinformation-ahead-election?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Big Tech Right Now
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Good place gif" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=377 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/l4pSWNYwJLYE6UkU0/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Good place gif" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/l4pSWNYwJLYE6UkU0/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">With the 2020 election looming, major tech platforms are scrambling to get their houses in order. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Setting the scene:</strong> Election Day is 60 days out. Many experts are worried that social media platforms will amplify election shenanigans, especially given the seismic slip-ups of the last presidential cycle (remember Cambridge Analytica?). And there’s even more at stake now, what with the global pandemic. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">First up, 2016’s chief tech villain </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Aka Facebook. Yesterday, CEO Mark Zuckerberg <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/03/facebook-to-ban-political-ads-in-week-before-presidential-election.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">announced</a> new moves to curb misinformation and ensure a smooth electoral process. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Facebook will not accept new political ads in the week leading up to Nov. 3. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>If any candidate attempts to declare victory before the final results are tallied, Facebook will link the post to vote counts from Reuters and the National Election Pool. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">These measures go further than Mark “Free Speech Crusader” Zuckerberg has gone before, but critics <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/03/facebooks-ban-on-new-political-ads-wont-change-anything.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pounced immediately</a>, arguing they’re the misinformation-banning equivalent of Louisiana Hot Sauce when the electoral system needs Mad Dog. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Pinterest demonstrated a stricter approach by banning ads on election-related search terms. It banned all political ads two years ago. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Second up, 2001’s chief tech villain</strong>: Microsoft. This week, the software giant <a href="https://nypost.com/2020/09/03/microsoft-launches-tool-to-spot-deepfakes-ahead-of-us-elections/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">released</a> a tool that can help spot deepfakes, or photos and videos that have been manipulated by AI. Microsoft said the tool will be made available to “organizations involved in the democratic process.” </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Third up, all of Silicon Valley </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Well, almost. <a href="https://www.axios.com/2020-election-gatekeepers-chaos-scenarios-84181512-1fca-4b84-8c10-e95e02e95f61.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Axios reports</a> that Facebook, Google, Twitter, and Reddit are holding regular meetings with each other, federal law enforcement, and intelligence agencies. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For what? Book club. No, they’re coordinating how to handle what’s expected to be a historic election for mail-in voting. That’s especially tricky because election officials may be counting ballots for days or weeks after Election Day, likely causing confusion. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>This year, the responsibility of electoral integrity is falling on U.S. tech companies nearly as much as on the government.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
EVENTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/03/ifa-trade-show-kicks-off-berlin?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Hey Look, Networking
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="People trying a Wessel Werk vacuum cleaner at the 2020 IFA trade fair " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMzA3L2lmYV90cmFkZV9mYWlyLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Sean Gallup/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday the IFA consumer electronics show kicked off in Berlin, and guess what? It’s not completely virtual. What a world!</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Sure, it’s <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/08/28/ifas-executive-director-discusses-why-the-tech-show-must-go-on/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">scaled down</a> dramatically. Last year, the show had 2,300 exhibitors; this year, about 180. And instead of using 40 halls, IFA 2020 will only take up five. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory: </strong>For the tech industry, the pandemic first hit home when Mobile World Congress, the largest phone show in the world, <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2020/2/12/21127754/mwc-2020-canceled-coronavirus-trade-show-phone-mobile-world-congress-gsma-statement?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">canceled</a> its event in February over coronavirus fears. In the months since, trade fairs around the world transitioned online as the pandemic halted physical gatherings. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Now, the convention economy is beginning to <a href="https://www.inquirer.com/real-estate/inga-saffron/convention-business-coronavirus-philadelphia-revenue-20200804.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">tiptoe</a> back to life, one breakout session at a time. On July 24, Orlando hosted 1,400 people for the “<a href="https://newsroom.ocfl.net/2020/08/orange-county-convention-center-hosts-together-again-expo/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Together Again Expo</a>,” a trade show all about trade shows during a pandemic.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>No one knows whether the trade show circuit will ever be the same—and for those of us who don’t know how to end a conversation, maybe that’s a good thing. But any real recovery could be years out: Vegas’s huge CES show in January 2021 is <a href="https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/ces-2021-las-vegas-canceled-digital-trade-show-1234717388/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">all-virtual</a>. </p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
INVESTING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/03/critics-take-aim-traditional-6040-investment-portfolio?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
60/40 Under Attack
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="a dinosaur in a canyon" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMzEyL2Rpbm9zYXVyX2Nhbnlvbi5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Pixabay</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We could be entering the Late Cretaceous period for the 60/40 investment portfolio, with a wave of critics forming an asteroid to wipe it out.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The latest naysayer: Paul McCulley, the former chief economist at investment giant PIMCO. On Bloomberg’s <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-03/if-60-40-keeps-working-democracy-has-failed-paul-mcculley-says?srnd=premium&sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Odd Lots </em>podcast</a> this week, he said that if the 60/40 portfolio keeps working, “then democracy has failed.” </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Okay, maybe it’s time to back up. </strong>The 60/40 investment portfolio encourages financial planners to invest in 60% equities and 40% bonds to achieve long-term success. It’s been <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-08-28/the-60-40-portfolio-split-between-equities-and-bonds-is-facing-serious-challenge?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">coded</a> into Wall Street’s DNA for decades, and provided solid returns for almost as long.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But increasingly, financial sages like McCulley argue that the Fed’s attempts to tamp down inflation have suppressed bond yields while inflating equity valuations—keeping the 60/40 split from working the way it’s supposed to. McCulley thinks this “disinflationary environment” that made the 60/40 mix an antique reflects larger systemic problems in the U.S. economy. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">So what now? </strong>A whole lot of experimentation is underway, including expansion into alternative investments like real estate. </p>

</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Jeep Wagoneer" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMzEzL2plZXBfd2Fnb25lZXIuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Jeep</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Into the fancy SUV market. Fiat Chrysler (FCA)’s Jeep brand yesterday <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-autos-fiat-chrysler-wagoneer/jeep-rolls-out-wagoneer-suvs-in-challenge-to-gm-and-ford-idUSKBN25U2T5?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">unveiled</a> two new luxury SUV models—the Wagoneer and the Grand Wagoneer.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If that made Fleetwood Mac play in your mind...yes, the name is a throwback to a 1970s model. Some specs: </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The Wagoneer will cost about $60,000, while the fully-loaded Grand Wagoneer is expected to cost north of $100,000. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>While the original model featured the famous wood paneling, the one revealed yesterday has subtler teak finishes, plus multimedia displays. CNBC </span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/03/jeep-grand-wagoneer-suv-to-top-100000-as-brands-luxury-flagship.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">described</a></span><span> the interior as “a digital cockpit.” </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>Luxury SUVs represent a highly profitable category in an otherwise lagging North American auto market. It’s also a competitive one—the Wagoneer will go up against GM’s GMC Yukon and Cadillac Escalade, and Ford’s Expedition and Lincoln Navigator. Eventually, Jeep wants the vehicle to be uttered in the same breath as the vaunted Range Rover. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> FCA’s other properties, Chrysler and Dodge, are struggling, so it’s hoping a souped-up SUV can <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/fiat-chrysler-showcases-jeep-with-new-models-stand-alone-showrooms-11599130812?mod=hp_lista_pos1&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">turn its fortunes around</a> by catering to the upper tax brackets.</p>

Big Tech \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/02/stock-market-futures-open-to-close-news.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edragged down\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e the major U.S. indexes to their steepest drops in months yesterday. Many analysts say this was a healthy pullback from weeks of ludicrous gains.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eTrade: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe U.S. trade deficit (difference between imports and exports) grew to its \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/dd93ecd3cafc5df88a8f9f4a61693b07?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehighest level\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e since 2008 in July. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eJobs: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eNew jobless claims = \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-economy/u-s-weekly-jobless-claims-below-one-million-but-labor-market-recovery-ebbing-idUSKBN25U1WS?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e881,000 last week\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, better than expectations. However, this was the first weekly report that reflected a new Labor Department methodology for calculating seasonal fluctuations. The big August jobs report is out this morning. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso ]\u003e\u003c! -- --\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- \u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c!-- END MARKETS --\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE ---\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso ]\u003e\u003c! -- --\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"c6 \" style=\"margin-bottom:7px\"\u003e\n\u003c!-- \u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003cth class=\"card\" style=\"text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px\"\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding: 15px;\"\u003e\n\u003ch3 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nTECH\n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/03/tech-platforms-implement-measures-curb-misinformation-ahead-election?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nBig Tech Right Now\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if mso]\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Good place gif\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" height=377 src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/l4pSWNYwJLYE6UkU0/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso]\u003e--\u003e\u003c!-- --\u003e\n\u003cimg class=\"story-header-image\" alt=\"Good place gif\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/l4pSWNYwJLYE6UkU0/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c!--\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWith the 2020 election looming, major tech platforms are scrambling to get their houses in order. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSetting the scene:\u003c/strong\u003e Election Day is 60 days out. Many experts are worried that social media platforms will amplify election shenanigans, especially given the seismic slip-ups of the last presidential cycle (remember Cambridge Analytica?). And there’s even more at stake now, what with the global pandemic. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eFirst up, 2016’s chief tech villain \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAka Facebook. Yesterday, CEO Mark Zuckerberg \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/03/facebook-to-ban-political-ads-in-week-before-presidential-election.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eannounced\u003c/a\u003e new moves to curb misinformation and ensure a smooth electoral process. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eFacebook will not accept new political ads in the week leading up to Nov. 3. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIf any candidate attempts to declare victory before the final results are tallied, Facebook will link the post to vote counts from Reuters and the National Election Pool. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThese measures go further than Mark “Free Speech Crusader” Zuckerberg has gone before, but critics \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/03/facebooks-ban-on-new-political-ads-wont-change-anything.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epounced immediately\u003c/a\u003e, arguing they’re the misinformation-banning equivalent of Louisiana Hot Sauce when the electoral system needs Mad Dog. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePinterest demonstrated a stricter approach by banning ads on election-related search terms. It banned all political ads two years ago. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSecond up, 2001’s chief tech villain\u003c/strong\u003e: Microsoft. This week, the software giant \u003ca href=\"https://nypost.com/2020/09/03/microsoft-launches-tool-to-spot-deepfakes-ahead-of-us-elections/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereleased\u003c/a\u003e a tool that can help spot deepfakes, or photos and videos that have been manipulated by AI. Microsoft said the tool will be made available to “organizations involved in the democratic process.” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThird up, all of Silicon Valley \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWell, almost. \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/2020-election-gatekeepers-chaos-scenarios-84181512-1fca-4b84-8c10-e95e02e95f61.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAxios reports\u003c/a\u003e that Facebook, Google, Twitter, and Reddit are holding regular meetings with each other, federal law enforcement, and intelligence agencies. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFor what? Book club. No, they’re coordinating how to handle what’s expected to be a historic election for mail-in voting. That’s especially tricky because election officials may be counting ballots for days or weeks after Election Day, likely causing confusion. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eThis year, the responsibility of electoral integrity is falling on U.S. tech companies nearly as much as on the government.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday the IFA consumer electronics show kicked off in Berlin, and guess what? It’s not completely virtual. What a world!\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSure, it’s \u003ca href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2020/08/28/ifas-executive-director-discusses-why-the-tech-show-must-go-on/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003escaled down\u003c/a\u003e dramatically. Last year, the show had 2,300 exhibitors; this year, about 180. And instead of using 40 halls, IFA 2020 will only take up five. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory: \u003c/strong\u003eFor the tech industry, the pandemic first hit home when Mobile World Congress, the largest phone show in the world, \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2020/2/12/21127754/mwc-2020-canceled-coronavirus-trade-show-phone-mobile-world-congress-gsma-statement?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecanceled\u003c/a\u003e its event in February over coronavirus fears. In the months since, trade fairs around the world transitioned online as the pandemic halted physical gatherings. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNow, the convention economy is beginning to \u003ca href=\"https://www.inquirer.com/real-estate/inga-saffron/convention-business-coronavirus-philadelphia-revenue-20200804.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etiptoe\u003c/a\u003e back to life, one breakout session at a time. On July 24, Orlando hosted 1,400 people for the “\u003ca href=\"https://newsroom.ocfl.net/2020/08/orange-county-convention-center-hosts-together-again-expo/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eTogether Again Expo\u003c/a\u003e,” a trade show all about trade shows during a pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eNo one knows whether the trade show circuit will ever be the same—and for those of us who don’t know how to end a conversation, maybe that’s a good thing. But any real recovery could be years out: Vegas’s huge CES show in January 2021 is \u003ca width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWe could be entering the Late Cretaceous period for the 60/40 investment portfolio, with a wave of critics forming an asteroid to wipe it out.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe latest naysayer: Paul McCulley, the former chief economist at investment giant PIMCO. On Bloomberg’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-03/if-60-40-keeps-working-democracy-has-failed-paul-mcculley-says?srnd=premium\u0026sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eOdd Lots \u003c/em\u003epodcast\u003c/a\u003e this week, he said that if the 60/40 portfolio keeps working, “then democracy has failed.” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eOkay, maybe it’s time to back up. \u003c/strong\u003eThe 60/40 investment portfolio encourages financial planners to invest in 60% equities and 40% bonds to achieve long-term success. It’s been \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-08-28/the-60-40-portfolio-split-between-equities-and-bonds-is-facing-serious-challenge?sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecoded\u003c/a\u003e into Wall Street’s DNA for decades, and provided solid returns for almost as long.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut increasingly, financial sages like McCulley argue that the Fed’s attempts to tamp down inflation have suppressed bond yields while inflating equity valuations—keeping the 60/40 split from working the way it’s supposed to. McCulley thinks this “disinflationary environment” that made the 60/40 mix an antique reflects larger systemic problems in the U.S. economy. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSo what now? \u003c/strong\u003eA whole lot of experimentation is underway, including expansion into alternative investments like real estate. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: Fiat Chrysler (FCA)’s Jeep brand yesterday \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-autos-fiat-chrysler-wagoneer/jeep-rolls-out-wagoneer-suvs-in-challenge-to-gm-and-ford-idUSKBN25U2T5?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eunveiled\u003c/a\u003e two new luxury SUV models—the Wagoneer and the Grand Wagoneer.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf that made Fleetwood Mac play in your mind...yes, the name is a throwback to a 1970s model. Some specs: \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe Wagoneer will cost about $60,000, while the fully-loaded Grand Wagoneer is expected to cost north of $100,000. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eWhile the original model featured the famous wood paneling, the one revealed yesterday has subtler teak finishes, plus multimedia displays. CNBC \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/03/jeep-grand-wagoneer-suv-to-top-100000-as-brands-luxury-flagship.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edescribed\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e the interior as “a digital cockpit.” \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eLuxury SUVs represent a highly profitable category in an otherwise lagging North American auto market. It’s also a competitive one—the Wagoneer will go up against GM’s GMC Yukon and Cadillac Escalade, and Ford’s Expedition and Lincoln Navigator. Eventually, Jeep wants the vehicle to be uttered in the same breath as the vaunted Range Rover. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line:\u003c/strong\u003e FCA’s other properties, Chrysler and Dodge, are struggling, so it’s hoping a souped-up SUV can \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/fiat-chrysler-showcases-jeep-with-new-models-stand-alone-showrooms-11599130812?mod=hp_lista_pos1\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eturn its fortunes around\u003c/a\u003e by catering to the upper tax brackets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-top: 12px;\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F09%2F03%2Fjeep-unveils-new-trickedout-luxury-suvs\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block;
